title: 104_s638
content: TERRITORIAL AND FREELY ASSOCIATED STATE INFRASTRUCTURE ASSISTANCE. Amendment to Section 4(b) of Public Law 94-241 limits payments to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands for fiscal years 1996 and beyond to amounts specified in the multi-year funding agreements. The special representatives of the President of the United States and the Governor of the Northern Mariana Islands must adhere to the Agreement's requirements. Additional funds in fiscal years can be used for capital projects in American Samoa. For fiscal years 1997 and beyond, funds are designated for capital infrastructure projects in Guam, the Virgin Islands, American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, Palau, Micronesia, and the Marshall Islands. In fiscal year 1997, $3 million is allocated to the College of the Northern Marianas, with a maximum of $3 million available annually starting from fiscal year 1997. In fiscal years beyond 1997, up to $3 million annually can be allocated for addressing immigration, labor, and law enforcement issues in the Northern Mariana Islands, including detention and corrections needs. Projects will be outlined in a five-year infrastructure assistance plan developed by the Secretary of the Interior in consultation with the island governments. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with island governments, develops a five-year plan for capital infrastructure needs, highlighting priority projects and considering master plans, Corps of Engineers' reviews, maintenance set-asides, and local involvement. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with island governments, develops a five-year plan for capital infrastructure needs, highlighting priority projects and considering master plans, Corps of Engineers' reviews, maintenance set-asides, and local involvement. Additionally, a provision allows for an emergency fund of up to $2 million per year, with a cumulative limit of $10 million, to be used in the event of natural disasters to supplement assistance for essential facility repair, replacement, or hardening. Additional contributions may be made within the allocated infrastructure funds to assist in the resettlement of Rongelap Atoll, with a total limit of $32 million from any Federal source after January 1, 1995. These contributions are contingent upon a satisfactory agreement to settle all obligations of the United States for resettlement activities. Federal agencies providing assistance in the Republic of the Marshall Islands can make funds available for the resettlement of Rongelap. The funds must be used solely for resettlement activities and will be audited. This does not limit ex gratia assistance for individuals who choose not to resettle. Federal agencies can provide funds for resettlement at Rongelap, with audits required. Ex gratia assistance is available for individuals who choose not to resettle, but only after full funding for Rongelap resettlement is confirmed by the Secretary to Congress. SEC. 2. FEDERAL MINIMUM WAGE. Effective thirty days after enactment, the minimum wage provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act will apply to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, with minimum wage rates set at $2.75 per hour initially, increasing to $3.05 per hour on January 1, 1996. Effective January 1, 1997, the minimum wage rate in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands will be raised by thirty cents per hour annually until it reaches the wage rate set forth in the Fair Labor Standards Act. Once it equals the FLSA rate, the minimum wage in the CNMI will be aligned with the FLSA rate. SEC. 3. REPORT. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with other government officials, must report to Congress by March 15 each fiscal year on funds allocated for immigration, labor, and law enforcement activities. The report includes immigration data, such as the number of non-US citizen contract workers in the CNMI. The Immigration and Naturalization Service may require the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands to report on non-US citizen contract workers, foreign government interference, laws' effect on Federal interests, detention facilities adequacy, and computerized alien data accuracy. The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands may need to report on the accuracy of the computerized alien tracking system and its compatibility with the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Federal agencies may require funding from the Secretary of the Interior to fully enforce laws in the region. SEC. 4. IMMIGRATION COOPERATION. The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands and the Immigration and Naturalization Service will work together to identify and potentially exclude or deport individuals posing security or law enforcement risks to the region. SEC. 5. CLARIFICATION OF LOCAL EMPLOYMENT IN THE MARIANAS. Section 8103(i) of title 46 of the United States Code is amended to allow aliens in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands to work as unlicensed seamen on certain vessels within the region's waters. Aliens in the CNMI can work as unlicensed seamen on certain vessels in the region's waters. Amendments to the United States Code allow them to be employed in the US under specific conditions. SEC. 6 clarifies ownership of submerged lands in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. Public Law 93-435 (88 Stat. 1210) is amended to include the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands in various sections previously mentioning Guam and the Virgin Islands. The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands is included in Public Law 93-435, with references to the date of enactment of this section. The Secretary of the Interior must provide an annual "State of the Islands" report to Congress on various territories, including economic development, federal assistance, local finances, infrastructure, and administrative capabilities. Section 501 of Public Law 95-134 is amended to include the Republic of Palau, the Republic of the Marshall Islands, and the Federated States of Micronesia. Passed by the Senate on July 20, 1995.
